turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: I did.  Boy.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Three kids.  What's she going to do?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: You said three minutes.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Won't take two.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Never shoulda given you that inventory in the first place.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: It's public record.  If the public cares enough to read it.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Here now, what are you fixin' to do?

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Have a look.  At nothing.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: You gonna climb that with one arm?

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: You're right.  I better use two.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: It's on the twine, too.  But it's not r...

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Don't prove there was two lanterns. Coulda been the one in the cabin.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: It's the way it happened, I know it is.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: No, you don't.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: This tastes horrible, hmmn?

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: You're wondering why I held it.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: I'm wondering how the judge is gonna like my waking up his old bones.  in the middle of the night.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Your daddy.  Was quite a feller.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Yes, he was.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: He's looking down.  And he's not thinking 'bout the man you were yesterday.  He's proud of the man you are tonight.  That's what counts.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: To my father.  Everything counts.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Tell us why that lantern would be so significant.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Well.  It shows the prosecutor was wrong.  It was <u>Carl's</u> boat that was dead in the water.  Or he'd never have put up the lantern.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Now you believe there were <u>two</u> lanterns when defendant arrived. One in Carl's hand.  The second lashed to the mast.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: That's what Mr. Miyamoto reported, and he'd have no reason to lie. He couldn't know that it would help his case.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Well, why does it?

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Because the second lantern, the one on the mast.  Was never found.  So we have to ask...

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: That's when he fell.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Fell.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Miyamoto gave him the battery, and left.  Carl's boat was running, he goes back to fishing.  But at some point, he thinks of the lantern...

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Still lashed to the mast.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: He figures a perfectly good lantern could get banged around up there.  So he climbs up.  To cut it down.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Just as the freighter comes through? Isn't that quite a coincidence?

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Coincidences happen.  You run a yellow light <u>just</u> as a car comes out of nowhere.  Split-second tragedy happens every day.  Or maybe...

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Maybe...?

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Maybe Carl picks up something about the freighter on his radio, which is now working.  Same report Milholland heard.  And <u>that</u> makes him get the lantern fast.  Before the freighter's wake can bang it around.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: But you <u>could</u> be wrong.  He <u>could</u> have climbed up earlier.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Then where's the lantern?  And where's the knife?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: The knife.  What knife?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Still a coincidence.  Timing and all.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: The freighter started through at 1:42.  The sea water seeped into Carl's watch and stopped it. At 1:47.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Still and all.  Carl was a strong swimmer, he m...

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: He hit his head.  On the way in.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: You think so?

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: The sheriff and the deputy and I inspected the deck closely.  We found a small fracture in the wood of the gunnel.  Just below the mast.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Well, anything coulda caused that.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Cigarette?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: I'll take two.  One for later.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: If I whistle.  Those boys'll see you, and come runnin'.  <u>You're</u> the story today.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: You ever been strangled by a single hand?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Naw, I've seen what that can do to a pack of cigarettes.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: We don't let go, you s...

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: It's a rare thing.  Takes a turning point.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: What for, Sheriff?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: We have a warrant.  To search your boat.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: You always run with the well open?

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: I was checking the cables.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: See you replaced a mooring line, lately.  This one's new.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: Naw, I had that around for a while.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Sure you did.  Help me with this hold cover, willya?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: You gaff with the <u>hook</u> end. Blood's on the butt.  Where your hand goes.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: Sure.  Blood gets all <u>over</u> your hand, Sheriff, ask any fisherman.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: Sheriff, I can't afford not to fish toni...

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Look, no way I'm lettin' you out there.  In a half hour you could be in Canada.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: What makes you think I play?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Your daddy played.  I asked, down at the Japanese Community Center. You smoke cigars?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: White or black?

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: You mean, do I like to take the offensive?  Or hang back and wait.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: You must think I like losing.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: I think you like learning.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Bet there's a few things you could teach me.  Kendo, for one.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: Sure.  I could take a fishing gaff and split your head open. Right above your left ear.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: You wouldn't even see it move.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: You're wonderin'...how come I never ask.  If you did it.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Now this jury is gonna be lookin' at the evidence with one eye. And at you with the oth...

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: Mr. Gudmundsson, we <u>know</u> what that jury is looking at.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: So every time you think about showing that jury strength.  Or honor or composure.  Or dignity.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: I should show them an American?

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: And what's that?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: That you came upon Carl by accident. Like you said.  Gave him the battery. Like you said.  Asked him about the seven acres.  Like you said.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: I'm more a hot-blooded killer, huh? Like a soldier.  Like a samurai.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: You won't hear that from Hooks. Because the charge is <u>first</u>-degree murder, which requires premeditation. He can't change the charge.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: You want me to say that.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: I want you.  To tell the truth.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: You think that <u>is</u> the truth.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: I told your wife.  Trials aren't always so much about actual truth. As about what folks <u>believe</u> is true. That's sad.  And it's real.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: And what do you believe?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Maybe the assailant straightened the cabin.  And forgot the cup.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Right.  In the middle.  Of the floor.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: I think you testified <u>all</u> the lights were on.  Cabin, mast, net lights, picking lights...

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Yessir, there'd been real heavy fog.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: And yet you started the engine right up.  With all those lights drawing all night, the batteries had that much charge.  Did that strike you odd?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Didn't think about it at the time. So no, it didn't strike me odd.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Does it now?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: A little.  Yes.  You have to wonder.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: You have to wonder.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: You found three batteries, you say.  A D-6 and D-8 in the well. And a spare D-8 on the cabin floor. Correct?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: It is.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Now I did some measuring down at the chandlery.  A D-6 is one inch wider than a D-8.  It would be too large for the deceased's well.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: He's done some on-the-spot refit- ting.  You could see the side flange was banged away to make room for the D-6.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: But he had a spare D-6, you said. Right there.  Why not use that?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: It was dead.  We had it tested. Maybe the D-6 was the spare and he had to use it.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Sheriff, how many batteries and what size did you find on <u>defendant's</u> boat?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Two D-6's.  That's the kind his well was fitted for.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: No spare.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: So the defendant went out fishing for the night with <u>no</u> spare battery, hmmn?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Apparently.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: I'm curious.  The D-6 that was refitted into the deceased's well. Was it exactly the same brand and model as defendant's?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: I believe so.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Now you've testified that the deceased was a heavy man, and hard to bring out of the net.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Is it possible his head struck the transom, or the stern gunnel, or the net roller, as you were bringing him in?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: You don't.  <u>Think</u> so.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: He was heavy, but we were real careful.  But I don't remember him hitting anything, anywhere.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: You don't.  <u>Remember</u>.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Operating this winch you'd rarely operated before, doing this awkward job of bringing in a drowned man of 235 pounds...is it <u>possible</u>.  Possible that he struck his head <u>after</u> death. Possible?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Possible.  But not darn likely.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: How <u>is</u> your mother-in-law?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: She's alright, Nels, thanks for asking.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: And her farmhouse...?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: The damage was considerable. But she's insured.  Thanks, again.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: One D-6 and one D-8 in the well. And a dead D-8 on the deck.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Which you inferred was replaced by the D-6, which must have been a spare.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: What else could it be?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Even though a D-6 is too big, and the flange had to be banged out to squeeze it in.  Which makes it a peculiar choice. For a spare.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: <u>You</u> said that.  That was <u>your</u> testimony.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: So this...foam you found in the lungs.  How does it get there?

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: As I testified.  It occurs when water, mucus and air are mixed by respiration.  I believe I said that.

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: That's <u>why</u> the autopsy report identifies <u>drowning</u> as the cause of death.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Meaning that he wasn't murdered first, say on the deck of the boat, and then thrown overboard.

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Your report says death by <u>drowning</u>, which means he went into the water alive and breathing.  And the report is accurate...?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: In your motorcycle example.  Those injuries are produced by the head being propelled <u>against</u> an object. Rather than the reverse, yes?

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: Obviously.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Can you tell whether an object moved against the head, or the other way around?  Or would both look the same.

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: The same.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: So if his head struck something narrow and flat, the gunnel of a boat, a net roller, a fairlead, could that have...

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: If the head was moving fast enough, but I don't see how it could be.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Is it possible?

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: Sure, anything's poss...

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Is it fair to say that you do not know for <u>certain</u> which it was.

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: I already said that, b...

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: <u>And</u> that you can't say for <u>certain</u> whether the head injury was sustained before or <u>after</u> death?

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: For certain, no.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: But you are <u>certain</u> that he died by drowning.

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: For the third time, yes.

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: Can I say something, here?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Yes, you can tell me about the minor cut you found on the deceased's right hand.  The report says 'recent origin'.  How recent?  As much as 24 hours before death?

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: Absolutely not.  Probably one or two hours.  Four at the most.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Are you absol...

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: <u>Yes</u>, I'm sure.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: So your husband said he's think it over.  Encouraged Mr. Miyamoto to believe he might sell to h...

turns.speaker: SUSAN MARIE
turns.text: I wouldn't say encouraged.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Well, he didn't say 'no', did he? Didn't say no hope existed.

turns.speaker: SUSAN MARIE
turns.text: Not in those words.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: So the defendant was encouraged to hope.  Or could have been.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: I guess you'd have to guess. Not having been there with them. Having to guess whether your husband's report was word for word accurate.

turns.speaker: SUSAN MARIE
turns.text: Carl never lied.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Of course not.  But it was emotional.  A friend's plea set against his mother's attitude.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Those 'dirty looks'.  Defendant ever aim one of those at you?

turns.speaker: SUSAN MARIE
turns.text: He had no reason to.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Carl ever say <u>he</u> got one?

turns.speaker: SUSAN MARIE
turns.text: I can't speak for him.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: You can speak for what he <u>said</u>. Just like you did for Mr. Hooks...

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Sorry about that, Mrs. Heine. Shall I repeat the ques...

turns.speaker: SUSAN MARIE
turns.text: Carl said he didn't like Kabuo much anymore.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: The question is more about the <u>defendant's</u> attitu...

turns.speaker: SUSAN MARIE
turns.text: That's all he said.

turns.speaker: CHURCH
turns.text: Improved...how?

turns.speaker: MEKUM
turns.text: As I said, in every way.  Physically and psychologically.  More endurance, quicker responses, better hand-eye, improved technical training.  Where the First Psychology gave you ninety-eight percent obedience, this bunch gives you 99.4.

turns.speaker: CHURCH
turns.text: Mmmmmm.  Weeell, you know my old daddy was in maintenance and he had a saying...

turns.speaker: CHURCH
turns.text: ...He used to say, "If it ain't broke, don't fix it."

turns.speaker: MEKUM
turns.text: I...see.  I'm not sure I quite get your...point...

turns.speaker: CHURCH
turns.text: Well, the soldiers we've got now, they've been through all kinds of heavy shit...and they've always got the job done.  Now these new ones, these "hot shots" of yours...what kind of action have they seen?  They <u>are</u> battle-tested, aren't they?

turns.speaker: MEKUM
turns.text: That's up to you field guys.  H.Q. wants you to break 'em in when you do the annual security sweep in January.

turns.speaker: CHURCH
turns.text: The sweep is just routine, not even police action.  I'd like to see some sort of...meaningful evidence...

turns.speaker: MEKUM
turns.text: Such as?

turns.speaker: CHURCH
turns.text: Maybe we could run some tests.  Kind of a comparison, the old and the new...

turns.speaker: MEKUM
turns.text: Melton, on the double!  Up a chain!                                   MELTON  Sir!     MELTON takes a few easy strides, gracefully catches a chain mid- stride, and smarts up, climbing easily and twice as fast as TODD.     CHURCH, SLOAN, and RUBRICK crane their necks as the two men struggle upward toward the rafters.     Three quarters of the way up, MELTON comes even with TODD, then passes him. MEKUM, watching, smirks.     CHURCH is watching too, and he's still not satisfied.  His brow is knit, something's bothering him.     ANGLE HIGH ABOVE, AMONG THE GIRDERS     Stonefaced, MELTON is resting an a "platform" on the chain, sixty feet up, beneath the girders, swaying gently.     His stony gaze is on the next chain where TODD is arriving at a "platform" on an adjacent chain...only three feet away.     Their eyes meet, TODD and MELTON alone together sixty feet up, three feet apart.  Neither man blinks, neither man flinches, neither man reveals anything at all...     LOW ANGLE, LOOKING UP     CHURCH considers the men high above, then to MEKUM.                                   CHURCH                    What about...spirit?

turns.speaker: MEKUM
turns.text: Spirit?                          Oh!  You mean "AQ"..."aggressive qualities"?

turns.speaker: CHURCH
turns.text: Whatever the latest jargon is.                                   MEKUM Much better, much higher.  For example, where your old ones expressed ninety percent of their sexual energy in aggressive physicality, these new ones are ninety-nine percent without sexual inclination.  It's <u>all</u> aggression.                                   SLOAN                          <u>Real</u> men!                                   CHURCH                          At ease, Lieutenant.                          What if they fought?     A sudden silence.     SLOAN raises her eyebrows, gives RUBRICK a look.     Frowning thoughtfully, MEKUM looks up. MEKUM You mean up there?                                   CHURCH                                             Go ahead, Rube.  Tell Todd to take him. MEKUM No!     They all look at MEKUM.  Is this the chink in the armor?  The new soldiers can't fight?                                   CHURCH                    "No"? MEKUM Not fair.  No contest.  Send two more of your old ones up.     Now CHURCH, RUBRICK, and SLOAN are stunned.  They exchange a glance.                                   MEKUM Go ahead.

turns.speaker: BELLHOP
turns.text: Are these your bags?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yes.  And that one, too.

turns.speaker: BELLHOP
turns.text: Okay, doll.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I suppose you want a tip?

turns.speaker: BELLHOP
turns.text: Forget it, doll.  After all, you work here - I work here - and believe you me, it's nice to have you with the organization.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Bye.

turns.speaker: BELLHOP
turns.text: Listen, doll - what time do you get off tonight?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: BELLHOP
turns.text: Because I'm working the night shift - and I got a bottle of gin stashed away - and as soon as there's a lull -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Aren't you a little too young for that, sonny?

turns.speaker: BELLHOP
turns.text: Wanna see my driver's license?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Get lost, will you?

turns.speaker: BELLHOP
turns.text: That's the way I like 'em - big and sassy.  And get rid of your roommate.

turns.speaker: BELLHOP
turns.text: Which of you dolls is Daphne?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Bull fiddle.

turns.speaker: BELLHOP
turns.text: It's from Satchel Mouth at Table Seven.  This is from me to you, doll.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Beat it, Buster.

turns.speaker: BELLHOP
turns.text: Never mind leaving your door open - I got a passkey.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Those idiot broads!  Here we are all packed to go to Miami, and what happens?  The saxophone runs off with a Bible salesman, and the bass fiddle gets herself pregnant.  I ought to fire you, Bienstock.

turns.speaker: BIENSTOCK
turns.text: Me?  I'm the manager of the band - not the night watchman.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Hi, Mary Lou - Rosella - Okay, Dolores, get a move on - How's your back, Olga?

turns.speaker: BIENSTOCK
turns.text: Clarinet - drums - trumpet - trombone -

turns.speaker: BIENSTOCK
turns.text: Yes, Sue?  What is it?

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: I thought I made it clear I don't want any drinking in this outfit.

turns.speaker: BIENSTOCK
turns.text: All right, girls.  Who does this belong to?  Come on, now.  Speak up.  Sugar, I warned you!

turns.speaker: BIENSTOCK
turns.text: I beg your pardon.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: All right, girls - from the top again.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: You know, Bienstock, there's something funny about those two new girls.

turns.speaker: BIENSTOCK
turns.text: Funny?  In what way?

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: I don't know - but I can feel it right here.  That's one good thing about ulcers - it's like a burglar alarm going off inside you.

turns.speaker: BIENSTOCK
turns.text: You're in Berths 7 and 7A.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Thank you ever so.

turns.speaker: BIENSTOCK
turns.text: You're welcome.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It's entirely mutual.

turns.speaker: BIENSTOCK
turns.text: Upsy-daisy.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Fresh!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: No --- how does it go?

turns.speaker: BIENSTOCK
turns.text: Now cut that out, girls-none of that rough talk.  They went to a conservatory.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Pardon me, Mr. Bienstock - can I have my flask back?

turns.speaker: BIENSTOCK
turns.text: You girls have seen a brown bag with a white stripe and my initials?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: A what?

turns.speaker: BIENSTOCK
turns.text: My suitcase - with all my resort clothes.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: This a private clambake, or can anybody join?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It's private.  Go away.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Manhattans?  This time of night?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: - so the one-legged jockey said -

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What did he say?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: The one-legged jockey said - 'Don't worry about me, baby.  I ride side-saddle.'

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Cut it out, girls.  Stop it. Joe - Josephine - help!

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Hey, she's ticklish!

turns.speaker: FIRST HENCHMAN
turns.text: Say, boss - I been talking to some of the other delegates - and the word is that Little Bonaparte is real sore about what happened to Toothpick Charlie.  Him and Charlie, they used to be choir boys together.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Stop, or I'll burst out crying.

turns.speaker: FIRST HENCHMAN
turns.text: He even got Charlie's last toothpick - the one from the garage - and had it gold-plated.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Like I was telling you - Little Bonaparte is getting soft.  He doesn't have it here any more.  Used to be like a rock.  Too bad.  I think it's time for him to retire.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Same faces - same instruments -  - and here's your Valentine's card.

turns.speaker: FIRST HENCHMAN
turns.text: Those two musicians from the garage!

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: They wouldn't be caught dead in Chicago - so we'll finish the job here.  Come on.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: FIRST HENCHMAN
turns.text: Me and Tiny, we had them cornered - but we lost 'em in the shuffle.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Where were you guys?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Say, Joe - tonight's the night, isn't it?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'll say.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I mean, we get paid tonight, don't we?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yeah.  Why?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Because I lost a filling in my back tooth. I gotta go to the dentist tomorrow.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Dentist?  We been out of work for four months - and you want to blow your first week's pay on your teeth?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It's just a little inlay - it doesn't even have to be gold -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: How can you be so selfish?  We owe back rent - we're in four eighty-nine bucks to Moe's Delicatessen - we're being sued by three Chinese lawyers because our check bounced at the laundry - we've borrowed money from every girl in the line -

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You're right, Joe.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Of course I am.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: First thing tomorrow we're going to pay everybody a little something on account.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: No we're not.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: We're not?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: First thing tomorrow we're going out to the dog track and put the whole bundle on Greased Lightning.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You're going to bet my money on a dog?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: He's a shoo-in.  I got the word from Max the waiter - his brother-in-law is the electrician who wires the rabbit -

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What are you giving me with the rabbit?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Look at those odds - ten to one. If he wins, we can pay everybody.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: But suppose he loses?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What are you worried about?  This job is going to last a long time.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: But suppose it doesn't?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Jerry-boy - why do you have to paint everything so black? Suppose you get hit by a truck? Suppose the stock market crashes?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Suppose Mary Pickford divorces Douglas Fairbanks?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Hey, Joe!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Suppose Lake Michigan overflows?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Don't look now - but the whole town is under water!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Well, that solves one problem.  We don't have to worry about who to pay first.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Quiet - I'm thinking.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Of course, the landlady is going to lock us out - Moe said no more knackwurst on credit - and we can't borrow any more from the girls, because they're on their way to jail -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Shut up, will you?  I wonder how much Sam the Bookie will give up for our overcoats?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Sam the Bookie?  Nothing doing!  You're not putting my overcoat on that dog!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I told you - it's a sure thing.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: But we'll freeze - it's below zero - we'll catch pneumonia.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Look, stupid, he's ten to one.  Tomorrow, we'll have twenty overcoats!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Greased Lightning!  Why do I listen to you? I ought to have my head examined!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I thought you weren't talking to me.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Look at the bull fiddle - it's dressed warmer than I am.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Yeah - where were you?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: With you.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: With me?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Don't you remember?  He has this bad tooth - it got impacted - the whole jaw swole up -

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It did?  Boy, did it ever!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: So I had to rush him to the hospital and give him a transfusion...  Right?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Right.  We have the same blood type...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: - Type O.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Nellie told us about it.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: We're not too late, are we?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You mean it's a girls' band?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yeah, that's what he means. Good old Nellie!  I ought to wring her neck!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: No.  And he ain't been eating so good, either. He's got an empty stomach and it's gone to his head.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: But, Joe - three weeks in Florida!  We could borrow some clothes from the girls in the chorus -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You've flipped your wig!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Now you're talking!  We pick up a couple of second-hand wigs - a little padding here and there - call ourselves Josephine and Geraldine -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Josephine and Geraldine!  Come on!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: All the way to Urbana - for a one night stand?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It's twelve bucks.  We can get one of the overcoats out of hock.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It's a hundred miles, Joe - it's snowing - how are we going to get there?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'll think of something.  Don't crowd me.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: We could've had three weeks in Florida - all expenses paid.  Lying around in the sun - palm trees - frying fish...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Knock it off, will you?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We didn't see anything -  - did we?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: No - nothing.  Besides, it's none of our business if you guys want to knock each other off -

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I think they got me.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: They got the bull-fiddle.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You don't see any blood?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Not yet.  But if those guys catch us, there'll be blood all over.  Type O.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Where are we running, Joe?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: As far away as possible.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: That's not far enough.  You don't know those guys!  But they know us.  Every hood in Chicago will be looking for us -

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You going to call the police?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: The police?  We'd never live to testify. Not against Spats Colombo.  Wabash 1098.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: We got to get out of town.  Maybe we ought to grow beards.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We are going out of town.  But we're going to shave.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Shave?  At a time like this?  Those guys got machine guns - they're going to blast our heads off - and you want to shave?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Shave our legs, stupid.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: How can they walk on these things? How do they keep their balance?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Must be the way their weight is distributed. Come on.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: And it's so drafty.  They must be catching colds all the time.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Quit stalling.  We'll miss the train.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I feel so naked.  Like everybody's looking at me.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: With those legs?  Are you crazy?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: It's no use.  We'll never get away with it, Joe.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: The name is Josephine.  And it was your idea in the first place.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Who are we kidding?  Look at that - look how she moves - it's like jello on springs - they must have some sort of a built-in motor. I tell you it's a whole different sex.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What are you afraid of?  Nobody's asking you to have a baby.  This is just to get out of town. The minute we hit Florida, we'll blow this set-up.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: This time I'm not going to let you talk me into something that...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: My name is Josephine.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: And I'm Daphne.
